div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

Friday, July 12, 1907.

div.head: COTTON TRADE PROFITS.
div.p: Reviewing the cotton trade during the past six months, the "Financier" remarks, that, while the industry is now again in a state of transition, the issue of which is doubtful, owing to the high price of cotton, and the prospects of a limited supply, it is certain that the past half-year has been highly profitable, like the previous twelve months.

Various statements have been made as to fabulous profits lately earned by the cotton spinning companies. It has been said that 30 and 40 per cent dividends have been common, while large bonuses have also been paid, immense sums placed to reserve, and some companies have built extensions or new mills out of profits.

There is some truth in these reports, but they refer to exceptional cases, and are not to be taken as showing the general run of results. Not all the companies publish their balance sheets, or even their dividends. Among many of the newer mills a policy of secrecy is observed'; the balance sheet is simply read at the shareholders meeting, and even those who have invested loan capital are not informed of the results. Most of the older companies, and some of the new ones however, keep up the custom of publishing quarterly or half-yearly dividends, and from these we can get a fair idea of the profits of the industry generally. We have before us now a list of the past six months' results of 135 mills, mostly spinning mills, and the majority in the Oldham, Rochdale and Manchester district. A number of these are new mills making their first report or fills which have been built within the past three years, but most of them are old-established concerns of the total number 92-the great majority-have paid 10 per cent.: several have paid less—5, 7 and 8 per cent., and one or two only 5 per cent.

On the other hand, there are about a dosen whose dividends range from 11 to 16 per cent. Then we find in the list dividends of 30, 26, 20, 35, 20, 20, 37, 20, 40, 35 and 20 per cent. In a number of cases the dividends would undoubtedly have been much larger, but the companies had heavy adverse balances to wipe out, the result of the previous spell of lean yours, before they could begin to pay dividends again. In most cases wams, larger or smaller, have been placed to reserve.

div.head: Police Report
div.p: Eight theft, 2 misdemeanors and 50 minor offences were registered during the course of Wednesday.

div.head: Lege Cut off
div.p: Yesterday afternoon Berberine landed both his legs cut off by a tram in Tewfik Pasha Street, Alexandria

div.head: An Italian's Suicide
div.p: This morning an Italian was discovered hanging dead in his bedroom at an hotel in the Place des Consuls, Alexandria. The Italian Consulate has opened an enquiry. It is believed to be a case of suicide.

div.head: Sudan Stores
div.p: The Transport Office of the Department of Stores has been moved from Gezireh Nile siding to Shellal. All forwarding work for the Army will in future be carried on at Shellal, and packages should be addressed accordingly.

div.head: A Life Sentence
div.p: The Native Court of Appeal has condemned Hassan Soliman Moswali to a life sentence of penal servitude with hard labour, It will e semembered that the prisoner was arrested in May Inst, on a charge of murdering Abdalla Mohamed

div.head: The OrientLine.
div.p: The Australian Government has cancelled the contract with the mail syndicate. The mail contract with the Orient Pacific Line has been renewed for a year, with the same subsidy as before. French tenders have been invited for a mail service, to commence on March 1 1908.

div.head: Public House Brawl
div.p: Yesterday evening about 9 o'clock, a Berberin seated in a public house of Hamamil-street strucks Syrian woman attendant with a stick and injured her in the neck. The woman cried for help and the proprietor of the house rushed ap and plunged a knife into the Berberin, who was removed to hospital

div.head: Mrs Eld's Accident
div.p: Dr. Eld has sent an application to the Belgian Consular Court at Cairo to order the Tramway Company to arrange as to the nomination of a medical expert to report on the condition of Mrs. and Miss Eid and their friend, who were injured while driving by a tram. It will be remembered that Mr. Eid's coachman has succumbed to his injuries.

div.head: The French Fete,
div.p: The French fete, which is to be held on Sunday in Cairo, promises to eclipse all previous celebrations of the 14th of July. The garden decorations are almost completed, and will, we can see, prove quite as effective as ever, while the evening's programine is most lavish and exhaustive. The committee has worked thoroughly and have guaranteed great success by their untiring and effective efforts.

div.head: Fatal Accidents.
div.p: On Wednesday morning last, at about 11 o'clock, a native lady, while crossing Sharia Mancha, was knocked down by an omnibus, the wheel of which passed completely over her body causing severe injuries, from the effects of which she died on the way to hospital. On the same day a native workman fell from a scaffolding of a house under construction in Sharis Foum el Khalig and was instantly killed.

div.head: Burglary in Cairo.
div.p: Assaad Haddad, a tobacco merchant at Zaptel, has lodged a complaint at the Kism police station, to the effect that some burglars forcibly entered his shop during the night, by means of a breach which they had made with pickaxes in the wall, and stole some LE 20 in hank notes and took away quantities of tobacco banned at LE. 20. The police have taken the case in hand, but us yet no arrests have been made.

div.head: Swimming Bath on the Nile
div.p: The concession which was granted for the construction of a swimming bath on the banks of the Nile at Cairo is for a period of 5 years. If at the end of that period the concession is not renewed, from one cause or another, the concessionaire will be called upon to vacate the place and to remove all material pertaining to the establishment. The building will be 40 metres in length by 80 metres broad and it is estimated will take 9 months - to erect.

div.head: Insults to European Women.
div.p: Some severe measures must be taken to put a stop to the insulting conduct of the Berberines to European women of Alexandria. Yesterday at 7 p.m. a European girl with three children was coming back from the Parks down Rue d'Allemagne. Suddenly a Berberine, evidently of the servant class, came up to her and touched her breasts. She repulsed him and he immediately retaliated by hitting her with a small cane he had in his hand. A middle aged Greek in the immediate neighbourhood, who witnessed this scene, went to the Berberine and struck at him. At once all the Berbereens rushed up and gave him a thrashing. The bowabs from the houses then also came to the aid of the Berberine and joined in attacking the Greek. Fortunately two policemen, an Italian and a native, came up. The native policeman did not interfere, as is not infrequently the case. The Italian, however, forced the Berberine to accompany him to the caracol, but he struggled so violently that two ghaffairs had to assist the Italian. The "Phare d'Alexandrie" draws attention to the generally repulsive behaviour of the Berberis in its issue of Wednesday in response to numerous complaints received from its readers.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT. EGYPTIAN DAY DEMANDED. FOREIGN INVESTMENTS IN EGYPT
div.p: Sir H. Campbell Bannerman, replying to Mr. Rutherford, declined to allot a day every session to discuss Beyptian affairs. (Reuter)

Mr. John Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he could states approximately the amount of native and foreign capital now invested in public companies in Egypt, the number of fore ign companies trading in Egypt without being there registered, and what proportion they bore to the number of companies registered
Sir Grey said he would inquire whether statistics or other material was available from which the information asked for could be obtained
SIDI BAR NI POST.

In the House of Commons last Thursday Mr. J. Robertson (Northumberland, Tyneside) asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether the Egyptian Government had established a military post at Sidi Barani, on the north-west, 40 miles from the Turkish post at Solum, and near a Beduin encampment: and, if so, whether, in view of the danger of friction thus set up, he would not advise the Egyptian Government to enter into negotia. tions for the proper delimitation of the western frontier d Egypt. .

Sir E Grey.-The Egyptian Government has established a coastguard post to prevent smuggling at Sidi Barani, halfway between Solemn and Mera Matrah. There is nothing in this act which renders delimitation necessary, or is likely to give rise to friction. The chief trouble on the frontier has arisen from disputes, not between Turkish and Egyptian officials, but between the Beduin tribes.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S BIRTHDAY
div.p: To-day being the Believer's birthday anniversary salutes were fired at noon at Cairo, Alexandria, and Port Said. All Consulates flew their flags, and several of the large business houses floated the Ottoman banner. The reception held by the Regent at Ras el Tin was very largely attended.

div.head: NEW VICTORIA COLLEGE THE RECENT ACCIDENT.
div.p: The following is the conclusion of the report of the three experts nominated by the Mixed Courts, Alexandria, to enquire into the recent accident to the new Victoria College : "We have remarked generally that the care, especially necessary in so important a construct ion has been wanting, owing to an insufficient superintending staff, which should have been very large and carefully chosen.

"Our impression is as follows that, taking into consideration the importance of the buildings and the use to which they are to be put, it would be advisable to calm down effect cally the opinion of the public caused by the accident.

That, therefore, as a further precaution it would be advisable to ask the opinion and advice of an eminent specialist in architecture, of full competenoa, and whose advice could be accepted by everybody is unquestionable."

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
div.p: In reference to the latest development of the financial crisis as affecting some firms in the Mousky quarter of Cairo, which are connected with Manchester, we understand that the English banks are disposed to be in favour of any policy. Nothing, however, of a definite character has been arranged. A Cairo contemporary, "La Bourse Egyptienne" in its issue of yesterday's date, remarked as follows:

Suivant les dernières nouvelles, les banques de Manchester ont consenti à aider les trois maisons du Mousky. qui avaient valeurs timages refusés. Toute inquiétude immédiate est donc forte de ce opté : l'avenir paraît devoir s'arranger au mieux des intérêts de la place. Au surplus M. Rowlatt, gouverneur de la National Bank of Egypt s'emploie activement au règlement des questions pendantes et tout donne lieu de croire que ses démarches seront couronnée de succès.

This information is not quite exact as it is of too definite a character for nothing has been settled as yet. As to the statement in regard to the Governor of the National Bank of Expyt, we may add that that gentleman is at present at sen and is not taking any active part in the negotiations,

div.head: EGYPTIAN JOURNALISTS ABROAD.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel, of "Al Lewa," Hafiz Effendi Awad, of "Al Minbar," and Abou Namir Bey arrived in Paris yesterday from Egypt. Mustapha Kamel has been going about the capital in a fine motorcar paying visits to Madame and Adalb, Mustapha Bey, the son of Ibrahim Pasha Neghib.
Habe Effendi Awad left Paris this evening for London where I understand that this able journalist intends to make a speech.
Mustaps Pasha Kamel and his friend, Abou Nasir Bey, are staying in the Rue de Paix. He went to the Jardin de Paris in the evening. 12

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT MINISTERIAL CHANGES.
div.p: A section of the Cairo Press has of late began to give vent to more or less explicit statements as to the changes which Sir Eldon Gore contemplates in the fabric of the Egyptian Government. Some of our contemporary mare that changes of an absolutely cataclystic character are imminent, and that an entire reorganisation of the Egyptian Administration has been resolved on by Lord Cromer's cer. They declare that vast change ate impending in the Ministry of Finance, in the Moudiriehr, Gouvemonts, and Sub Gouver orists and that the entire scheme has already been drawn up. It is stated that nex Government will be formed with Saad Pasha Zaghloul as Prime Minister and that the suggested changes will be carried into effect on the return of the Ministers and Advisers from leave. Boutros Pasha Ghali will retain the Ministry of Poreign Affairs, but there will be, so it is with considerable changes in the Under Secretaries of States One of the questions which is specially interesting the quinones for the moment is the resignation of Sir Vincent Corbett, which is already erroneously seemed to be an accomplished Incl. Various reasons are adduced for the desire of the Pineal Advised to leave the mrvice of the option Government and resume his career in the Diplomatic Service. For example, "Les Pyramides remarks

On peleiserit, aujourd'hui les raisons qui Auraient mené Sir V..Corbett á prendre cette décision. Des ressentiments soient, dit-on, dilaté entre Sir Eldon Gorst et le Conseiller Financier, au sujet de la façon dont ce dernier a disposé du fonds slerinerve du gouvernement égyptien, dont une grande partie a déjà 16 employée pour les besoins de l'Etat et en avances au gouvernement du Soudan.
Sir Eldon Gorst aurait demandé ce que cette belle faite sur Tror sit amet comble Sir Vincent Corbett, considérant otte maître comme un diabou des gestion, as fait alors décidé de donner sa démission

As we have already stated nothing has yet been decided upon Sir Vincent Corbett thus express wish to rom his official.com infection with the Poreign Office, but no decision has as yet been arrived at us to the approximate date of his retirement from his present post. Sir Eldon Goest has various projects and his practical acquaintance with the intricacies of Egyptin administration will induce him to marry out some important changers. Ever since his nomination as Lord Cromer's successor, I have been carefully studying the needs of Egypt. As regarde any immediate and sweeping change, such as some newspapers appear to think is contemplated, we understand that no cut and dried scheme has yet been admitted by Sir Eldon Gors, and speculation at the present moment in a work of supererogation, or no decision will be come to until the return of the official world from Europe in the autumn.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Mr. Charles Greig Acting British Consul General for the City and Port of Alexandria, will preside over the British Consular Court on Monday next, the 15th inst, when an interesting est regarding the legal rights of British employes in Egypt will be decided The Counsel for the defence is Mr. Fred Moss, barrister at-law. The plaintiff will be represented by Mr. Halford, barrister-at-law. The argument on the points of law involved in this one are of a somewhat intricate chanoter and the judgment will be awaited with considerable interest. The proceedings will begin about 10 a.m.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES
div.p: We understand that this company has just completed the negotiations for the sale of one of their properties situated at Marsoarah. A very good price has been realised and the Company are to be congratulated on carrying the business through under the present conditions of the market 10 Mr. Montagu Summers, Managing Director of the Exyptian Batates, is returning to Egypt from London next week. Mr. Scott of the same company, ha retame from leave.

div.head: MINISTRY OP PUBLIC INSTRUCTION THE LAMBERT AFFAIR. FRENCH PRESS OPINION
div.p: Teis an article about the treatment of M. Lambert of the Khedivial School of Law (Beypt) was correct but was neither very just, friendly, nor clever and was not in CORROBOREE with the proced confidence characterising Anglo-French relations.(Reuter

"Al Watan" mars The most curious aspect of the opposition in the question connected with the Synod of Law is the vehemence of the students in denouncing the last step taken by the Government for putting the administration of that School on sound bases. Apparently there misguided youths, spoiled by the excessive leniency of the authorities, are infuriated at the Government's decision to dispense with the service of a Frenchman and appoint an Englishman in his place. Were the tourists here now with their soul cranks who believe they have solved every Egyptian problem after a stay of some day at Shepherd's the world would have long med a good deal about the Porch influence here. But we have no illusions about the facts of Food we can Mure our European readers that not one in a million among our countrymen prefers France to England in any way. The fact about the Law students that they are like their Irish friends against the Government and its men without knowing keyway. They belong to the Opposition party and take no trouble to deny this. Some of them, mitybe, are shrewd enough to perceive that the appointment of an English abiel will lead to change in the administration of their school. The laissez faire pagine will give place to the English businesslike way of directing the fins of a public school Naturally bagh our impulsive and irresponsible youths do not roue the change

We are not concerned here with the policy of the British Agency in using opposition to the appointment of Mr. Hill Bat we are bound to my that any deviation from the last decision and any compromise will be missed Sinatra. It will mean & new victory to the of opposition and agitation, and the stomach of the Nationalist party will require more mouthfuls of this food from time to aime... We will only add that we are in the Best where the ruling power ought to maintain prestige at all costs.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: The latest official bulletin reports that, besides the widow of the proprietor of the Hotel de la Poste having fallen victim to Hotel de la Poste having fallen a victim to bubonic plague, 2 servant girls, one of which is Italian and the other Greek, have been admitted into the hospital suffering from the disease.

One native woman has been found at Karmouz and a native man at Sit-Naimah, bubonic plague being diagnosed in each case. Port Said reports one native admitted to hospital, Beba three natives admitted to hospital, and Damanhour one native admitted to hospital, and one death, native. During the week ending the 8th July, 14 cases of bubonic plague were recorded throughout Egypt, of which occurred at Alex andria, 1 at Port Said, 1 st Beni-Sonel, 1 st Samallout, 6 at Damanhour, and 1 at Aneh. From the 1st of January to the 8th instant 960 cases of plague have been registered as against 876 cases reported during the corresponding period of last year.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamett Aly Pasha, who is now at Paris with Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, will proceed shortly to Kissingen to meet the Khedive.
Mohamed Bey Izzat, Chief of the Arabio Bureau of the Khedive, will remain at Constantinople until the return of the Khedive
- M. Philon, Greek Diplomatic Agent, arrived at Alexandria to pay the summer season.
Mr. Webb, Under Secretary of State for Irrigation and Acting Adviser to the Minister of Public Works, has returned to Cairo from his inspection of the works at Esneh barmage.
Mr. Webb will arrive at Alexandria to-day to present his annual report on rotations to Abani Pasha, Acting Minister of Public Works and will embark on Monday for England on two months' leave.
Adjutant Major Hussein Affendi Rifle who was a staff officer in the Sndan, has been appointed Arabie Secretary to the head office of the Railway Administration.

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL
div.p: The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from me 15 to October 1. [Apvr.)

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE. IMPERIAL TROOPS HARASSED. CHAOS IN UPPER YEMEN. (From our own correspondents.)
div.p: According to the latest reports to hand, Yemen is at present really disturbed and chaos is poised to reign there. The Imam has sent a number of his chiefs to raid Turkish districts, and generally those which are poorly, or not at all. garrisoned by Turkish troops, And to invest Sans From Dhammar and Yeim to Saha communications are cat of, and the greatest sufferers are the Arab Turkish web jects. Even on the coast and in the hinterland of Hodelda the Arab triber, who are not votaries of the Imam, are engaged in internal feeds, while communications between Hodeida and Manakha are more or less stopped, in con gence of these feudal.

Prom Manakha, an important strategic place lying nearly midway between Hodeida and Sans, and commanding both ways, the telnymph wire has been eaten by the mbele About twenty Turkish troops left Manakha with the post for Sana. They were interested on the way by the rebels, who killed several of them

The commander of the Imam, al Mikdad, is reported to have attacked Al Manar, Turkish district not garrisoned, and the Turks of Al Haine on getting went of his presence there, & force of the Imperial troops surrounded the place and attempted to eat, off his retros but in this they failed, immediately tuning movement was made by another body of the rebels who attacked the Turks, thus allowing Mildad to encape. The result of the enyonge ments that the Turks lost about 300 and the rebels about 100

div.head: SECRET SOCIETIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" make the following reflections in reference to the roomt articles ia "Al Watan on her societies in Egt One must agree with "El Watan" that the Frequency of these accusations and the evident is to which the Nationalist Press h ome m every instance to refute them, show that hey are not ill-founded The Coptio Journal maintains that the aim of the secret societies is o boycott British good to combat European their daily work, and to use onderhand me to counternet and oppose the work of Government officials whenever it clashes with Nationalist viens. These were societies will nly be able to work up to a certain point. The Government has a very efficient staff of secret service men all over the country, and undoubt edly it is fully informed of what is happening. But all the same, it is rather disconcerting to find that the Nationalist campaign has assumed this new phase. Evidently our Nationalista are blind to the lesson which they should learn from the result of recent events in India." WL

div.p: -- The building of the Cairo brewery of the British Beer Breweries (Egypt) is now completed and the plant is being installed. The Company will be ready for brewing in the autumn.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM THE ALTERATIONS
div.p: The level of the water above the dam, it will be remembered, is to be mined by about 23 ft, although the dam itself will only be heightened about 16 ft. The present maximum depth of water above the sills of the lowest sluice is about 61 it, but as the cal. verts are at different levels the increase in depth above referred to will add 117 per cent. to the head of water against some of them. However, the Stoney aloides were originally made in such a substantial manner that only a few of them at the higher levels will require slight Alteration to withstand this greater pressure. The plain sluices, of which there are fifty in the upper part of the dam, will not need any alteration. In fact, practically the only extra work required in connection with the sluices is the lengthening of the lifting ropes so that they can be operated from the top of the heightened dam. The substantial character of the sluices can, to some extent, be judged from the fact that each of those at the lowest level now supports a horizontal pressure of over 200 tons. They will have to carry more than 300 tons each when the dam is raised. A more important part of Messrs. Ransomes and Rapier's present contract is that concerning the metal work of the four locks which carry the navigation channel past the dam. The walls of the locks will each be raised from 14 to 20 f., 30 that the upper one (No. 1) esa open direction to the reservoir. A new lock will be constructed at the downstream end of the flight to share the extra lift which would otherwise have to be taken by No. 4 look. The existing gates will be moved and re-erected one lock further down, whilst two new gates will be fitted in No. 1 lock, These will be 78 f, 9 in. (24 metres) deep by 84 ft. wide. This great depth of gate is necessary because the head of water above the dam varies over very wide limits. When the reservoir is full the lift of the combined look will be some 90 ft. But when the water impounded has been run off there will be very little difference in level at the two ends of the flight of locks. Hence the two upstream lock gates must have their upper sills at the lower level and yet be high enough to communicate with the reservoir when fall. This lock would be able, of course, to pass vessels from one side of the dam to the other whatever the level on the oppor side, but the pressure of the water on the gates and walls would make such a scheme impracticable. They would have to withstand horizontal pressure of about 2,500 tons when this reservoir is full, but by adding the other four looks the load is shared out, although some of them will not be required at times of low water.

The gates, however, will be designed strong enough to take the full pressure of 2,500 tons should the lower looks become empty by accident. The moving of the enter, which weigh from 100 tons downwards each, into their new positions will be an interesting operation. They will have to be turned round to travel along the locks, lifted up and then lowered into the next look about 16 ff. below their original position These alterations to the locks will noch state the entire earrings tent of the bydraalio piping and machinery and to operate the gates, and an increase in the expacity of the hydraulic accumulators.
A new swing bridge is to be built over the upper end of the navigation channel. It is to be capable of carrying a 25-ton velling onne, and will be operated by Mind power.
Although these notes cover the tosin part of the context, there is a great quantity of detail work which it is Q C sary to describe. The whole of this work is to be completed in five years ol dala

div.head: WHERE ARE THE POLICE
div.p: TO THE BOTTOM OF THE "BYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir. How is it that the Alexandria Police appear to be utterly unable to exercise the slightest control over the rowdy behavior of sombofourlocal parvenir, who happen to possess motor ears! For example early this morning, about d'olock, the Old Bourse street was perfect pandemonium owing to the wanton behaviour of a person in a motor car. I happen to live in this street, and was awakened from my slumber by a terrible noin 10 shrill, ac ploring and so voluminous in sound that i jumped out of bed, fully persuaded the Alexandria Fire Brigade hid cote on the scene, and were determined to stoke the neighborhood owing to some dangerous conflagration in the vicinity. I looked into the street to see what could be the matter, for the noise continged, and it seemed though it was the shriek of an express train. To my indignation I found that it was a motor car which kept perambulating 'round 186 Building and blowing it hooter and white time. There was absolutely no need for this diature there was the cake about that early boor of the morning. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi).

La séance de ce matin à la corbeille des valeur a été le digne couronnement de toute une semaine d'inaction. Il n'y a pas d'acheteur et les quelques titres inscrita en hanno n'out eux-mêmes donné lieu à aucun échange. Cependant l'aspect de la corbeille, les cris des courants donnent par intervalles l'illusion de l'animation
Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, l'Agricole reste stationnaire à 7 3/4, tandis que la National Bank gagne 1/16 à 19 11/16 et la Delta Light 1/8 & 9 ¼
En hausse également la Behera de 25 à 25 1/2, les Lots Tures de 162 , 167, l'Anglo American Nile de 3 à 3 1/8, L'Urbaine de 3 11/16 A 3 7/8, le Banco di Roma de 105 1/2 106.

La santé la reprise. L'Anglo-Egyptian Spinning Mochit, au contraire, de 7/16 . 3/8, le Comptoir de 2 7/16 l'ancienne et 2 5/16 la nouvelle à 2 3/8 et 2 1/4 respectivement, la Banque d'Orient de 116 à 115 1/2.
La Bière du Caire s'inscrit à 108 ex-coupon In Privilégiée et 48 la Dividende, contre 115 et 45 respectivement.
En Cassa di Sconto, il y aurait eu un échange de 25 titres 29 francs. Quoi qu'il en soit, le prix inscrit en lecture est de 32 francs, soit le même qu'hier.

Il a été question pendant toute la matinée de l'Agricole, des Estates, de Crédit Pronos Égyptien, de l'Urbains, mais absolument sang affaires, ainsi que nous le disons au début. C'est pourquoi les fluctuations sont exceptionnellement clairsemées et encore celles inscrites ne sont-elles pas toujours justifiées.

La situation locale, loin de s'améliorer comme on l'espérait par la solution satisfaisante de la question de la Cassa di sconto, se complique de nouvelles circonstances défavorables qui étaient reliées au second plan tant qu'avait duré l'inquiétude causée par la fermeture de cette banque, mais qui défraient maintenant toutes les conversations. C'est la situation genre de plusieurs sociétés nouvelles et de nombreuses maisons de commerce.

Certains détenteurs de titres qui avaient tout fait pour tenir dans l'espoir d'une solution heureuse vers la fin de l'année prévoient maintenant la nécessité de s'alléger encore. Comme pour compliquer encore la situation, l'argent redevient cher à Londres. Il est vrai qu'aux bas cours actuels, l'Europe contingers d'absorber nos bonnes valeurs, mais il est difficile de prévoir le sort des autres
Ajoutons cependant qu'une bonne récolte et la renaissance de la confiance momentanément perdue pourraient tout sauver, attendu surtout que la prospérité effective de pays reste intacte.

loi, le marché de ce matin a été aussi calme que celui d'hier, avec tendance à la lourdeur sur divers titres. Le seul trait caractéristique de la séance a été un mouvement sur les Egyptian Hotels, qui ont gagné 5/8 sur le prix de előture de la veille

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National s'est maintenue à 19 11/16 et l'Agricole à 1 3/4-13/16. La Cassa di Sconto a été notée 85. Le Comptoir Financier a été ramené à 2 1/2-3/4 et sa part de fondateur d 2. La Banque d'Orient s'est raffermie à 115.
La D'airs a fléchi 18 1/8 et la Behera à 25 1/4. L'Enterprise and Development a faibli a 8 1/4. L'Allotement s'est établi à 2.
La Deltalight s'est alourdie à 9 1/8, les Heliopolis à 235 et les Jouissances Baux du Caire à 178-179.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Non Govich ont clôturé 15 1/2. En bonne tendance, les Egyptian ou passé de 4 1/2 à 5 1/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée à 1 9/16. La part de fondateur Estates est tombée à £ 4. Les Markets ont réactionné à 25 sh. Les Constructions ont faibli à 0 ⅜

La séance de la Bourse du Caire a été, ce matin, suspendue pour un quart d'heure à l'occasion de la mort de M. Campos, père de M. Alfred Campos, l'administrateur délégué de Comptoir Financier d'Egypte - Le comité de la Corporation a délégué à Alexandrie deux de ses membres pour assister aux obsèques.
Nous exprimons à la famille éprouvée nos plus sincères condoléances.
Suivant des informations télégraphique reçues bière de Londres, l'assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Estates Ltd. a été fixée au 26 Juillet courant

Du rapport du conseil d'administration, qui vient d'être publié, il résulte que les bénéfice de l'exercice selon le 81 Mars 1907 élèvent à £ 178,000, dont 68,700 seraient placés à la réserve statutaire et 15,000 la réserve spéciale, laissant en solde disponible de Lav. st. 100,001.
Le conseil d'administration ne unis a toutefois d'avis de distribuer, pour le moment, un dividende complémentaire, un dividende provisoire de 5 0/0 ayant été payé il y a quelques
Le rapport ajoute que des dispositions sont prises en vue d'une nouvelle émission d'obligations
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 5 Juillet, le passage suivant :
" Au Stock Exchange, les valeurs égyptien. nes ont eu, cette semaine, un marché soutenu. Les fluctuations n'ont pas été marquantes, mais il y a eu un bon courant d'affaires

*La National Bank clôture au même pours que la semaine dernière, soit 19 18/16, après avoir oscillé entre 19 5,8 et 20 1/4. De 7 16/16, l'Agricole s avancé à 8, avro d'assez nombreuses transactions aux environs de ces prix. LA Datar a faibli de 18 7/8 a 131,2 et la Delta Land de 1 15/16 à 1 3/4, toutes deux par suite d'ordres de vente provenant d'Egypte.

"Les Markets ont eu une demande suivre : leur cours avancé de 24/6 25/6 et quelques milliers de titres ont changé de main. Les Salt and Soda ont progressé de 18/6 à 19/-sur l'achat de quelques centaines de titres.

"Les Estates ont été de nouveau l'objet de ventes importantes pour compte de l'Egypte Leur prix a recole de o 29/32 a 16/- ; le plus bas en pratique a été 14 sh. 4 1/2. Leur part de fondateur a été négocié à £ 7.

"La New Egyptian a baissé de 16/9 à 15) La Khedivial Mail Ordinary, qui était depuis longtemps négligée, & trouvé aujourd'hui acquéreur à 24/ Quelques transactions ont eu lieu 'en United Lands aux abords de 9/- L'aboukir Land a été asse demande et son cours
passé de 1 9/16 a 1 3/4."

Dans le discours qu'il a prononcé l'assemblée générale ordinaire des Egyptian Hotels Ltd. à Londres le 1er Juillet 1907, lord Claud Hamilton, président du conseil d'administration de la Compagnie, a fait un exposé intéressant de la marche suivie par les affaires de la Société. . "Nous avons débuté, a-t-il dit en substance, avec une dette en obligations de £ 280,000, dont £ 141,400 ont été rachetées, en partie au moyen de fonds d'amortissement, mais principalement grâce à la réalisation du surplus des terres de notre domaine de Gezireh. Il ne reste plus que £ 188,600 d'obligations.

"La vente d'une partie de ce terrains disponibles sous a valu une somme de Liv. st. 250,000, sur lesquelles nous avons à recevoir Lat. 120,000. Nous avons encore en notre possession une superficie de 78,000 mètres carrés, en comprenant l'emplacement de Ghe zireh Palace Hotel. Ce terrain, situé sur ou près le Nil, a uno valoir que la construction d'un pont sur le fleuve, en face de notre propriété, est certainement appelée à croître en le mettant par le tramway à quelques minutes du centre de Caire."

" Ainsi qu'il falte de rapport, notre pro prid, appels enlisement des £120,000 pre ôtées et l'amortissement des obligations axis tante, consistera dans le Gheziel Palace Hotel et son mobilier, les 78,000 metros de terrain susmentionné en y comprenant le placement de l'hôtel, le Shepherd's Hotel son mobilier et ses attenzione, ayee un bal de 65 ans courir, à raison de £ 1,850 de loyer par an.
Cet actif est il me semble de nature faire amplement face à notre capital a no engagements, estimée en bloed $280,000 ainsi que l'établit le rapport de conseil."

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
div.p: AVIS

The Administration of the State Railways has the honour to inform the Public that, with a view to facilitating the goods work at Gablary station and in order to provide more Accommodation for unloading all the inward goods during the cotton won, it has been decided, after consultation with the AlexAndria Produce Association, that during the months, October 1st to January 31st each year, the withdrawal of cotton beled as Gabbary on Sundays will be obligatory, the making Banday an ordinary day, oh which demarrage will be collected in cases of delay
Merchants in their own interest as well as that of the Administration, are respectfully requested to make their arrangement accordingly.
The Administration begs all the attention of merchants to the fact that it will help matters considerably, if they can manage to withdraw as much cotton as possible.
Cairo, 8th July 1907. 30618-21

div.head: THE HOME FLEET. TO ASSEMBLE AT COWES. SWEDISH SQUADRON'S VISIT.

div.p: It is officially announced at Devonport that all the available ships of the Home Fleet will Assemble at Cowes on 30th instant for a demonstration, on the occasion of the Emperor William's visit during Cowes week. (Later).
The Home Fleet will assemble at Cowes to greet the Swedish squadron, not the Emperor William who is not coming before November (Reuter)

div.head: THE KING IN IRELAND. DUBLIN'S HEARTY OVATION.

div.p: The King and Queen received very hearty ovations here. They move to the Exhibition and to the Garden Party at the Viceregal lodge through streets packed with cheering crowds. (Reuter)

The King and Queen sent a message to the Lord Lieutenant thanking the Irish people for their hearty welcome. Their Majesties attended Leopardstown races in the afternoon, where they had a magnificent reception. (Reuter)

The organ of the War Office, commenting on the Hague Conference, says that Russia, exhausted by a disastrous war and internal troubles, cannot agree to a limitation of the use of submarine mines until her feet has been reconstructed and order restored (Renter)

div.head: GERMANY AND RUSSIA.TSAR TO MEET KAISER

div.p: It is reported that the Tsar and the Emperor William will meet in Norwegian waters next week. (Reuter) * Paris, July 11. The "Gaulois" announces that on the initiative of Emperor William the Tsar and Kaiser will meet next week. (Haras)

div.head: THE ITALIAN SENATE. THE NASI AFFAIR.

div.p: The Senate has adjourned. It will meet tomorrow in judgment upon ex-Minister Nasi. (Haras)

div.head: DJELAL BEY. MARRIED TO SULTAN'S DAUGHTER,

div.p: Djelal Bey, Rizi's son, has married a daughter of the Sultan. (Hanas)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AT BELGRADE. VISIT TO THE KING.

div.p: The Khedive has visited the King, who returned with him to the station. (Havas)

The "Standard" learns from St. Petersburg that though the bulk of diplomats and officials are absent on holiday, Sir A. Nicolson and M. Izvolky are still in the Capital, despite torrid heat, immersed in the Anglo-Ridssian negotia os which are proceeding without a hitch. It is expected that they will be concluded before the autumn. (Reuter)

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: Quelques petites erreurs s'étant glissées dans notre compte-rendu de la Délégation du 10 Juillet, en ce qui concerne le dallage des routes du Quai et la ventilation des égouts, nous publions pour ces questions le compte rendu officiel:

De l'avis conforme du Comité des travaux publics à l'examen duquel la question avait été renvoyée, la Délégation décide de proposer à la Commission Municipale l'ouverture d'un premier crédit de LE. 3000 pour le remplacement des regards actuels en pierre, qui se cassent constamment par des regards en fer et l'adoption d'un système de ventilation des égouts, proposé par l'Ingénieur en chef et destiné remédier aux émanations qui se dégagent de ces égouts.
Ce système sera étendu ultérieurement dans toute la Ville, après dépôt par l'Administrateur d'un projet financier pour l'accomplissement en entier desdits travaux et de ceux d'assainissement.

Communication est donnée d'une note de l'Ingénieur en chef soumettant un rapport au sujet des divers modes de pavage que l'on pourrait employer pour la promenade du quai et les diverses routes y aboutissant, proposant d'adopter de préférence pour le moment le pavage en dalles, sauf à établir ultérieurement un système de pavage définitif quand les quais seront bordés de constructions. Ce pavage en dalles nécessiterait une dépense de LE 44,000 pour une superficie de 80,000 m.o. environ. La Délégation adopte la proposition de l'Ingénieur en chef et décide de proposer à la Commission Municipale l'ouverture des crédits nécessaires pour ce pavage, demandant à M. l'Administrateur de vouloir bien, dès la rentrée, lui soumettre ses propositions financières pour l'accomplissement de ce travail qu'elle désire voir entreprendre au plus tôt.

div.head: CYPRUS.
div.p: MINERAL DEVELOPMENT.

It some strange that during the late mining boom in Egypt, while prospectors and engineers were patiently pursuing their weary search for metals in the arid deserts of Nobis or the Sudan, that one of the principal mineral fields of the ancients, ehsy of access, and at the very doors of Egypt, we may say, should lie practically prospected and undeveloped. We rafer of course to the island of Cyprus, at one time the scene of the greatest activity and industry in mineral working and mining. The ancient workers it is true were no amateurs at mining work, and of the more valuable minerals and metals, the use of which were known to them, very little is left which was within their roach. So well did they complete their work, that in the residues left by them there is nothing to warrant further treatment.

Cyprus is now beginning to take example from Egypt, and her people are themselves turning attention to the mineral possibilities, long dormant, of their country. The commerce of the present day demanda many minerals, the ses of which were unknown in the former days of prosperity, and of these the island is not deficient.
ASBESTOS.

Attention is very much directed at present to one of these, vis asbestos. The uses of this mineral at the present time are too numerous to mention, and there is an ever increasing demand for it. There are immense quantities of it existing in the mountains in the interior of the island. A visit to an asbestos mine the other day, near Mount Troodos, the development of which is being posted on by a syndicate formed in Trieste, proved very interesting Driving down the mountain road, the strata suddenly began to change, rocks which had hitherto conformed to the geneml formation were now streaked with white, until whole masses on the hillside took OR 4 whitish colour, making in their extra Iurreness a striking feature, as viewed from Troodos. On a spar of the mountain, the company mentioned have opened one or two faces, and where so opened up shows what is . veritable mountain of asbestos so white as to dazzle the eye. The fibre is as yet rather short, but apart from woven work there is a large demand for the manufacture of plaster for covering of much importance. In close proximity to the asbestos there are large bodies of soapstone: this is generally found in connection with asbestos, and is here so my of access that it may probably at no distant date, form a valuable commercial asset. On the Limassol side of the mountains there are also asbestos workings, the production of which has been favorably reported upon in England, and further samples asked for. Cyprus will in the near future be able to supply the market with a large output of the best quality.

It is believed that the Government intends cutting the timber on the hills, which has been carefully conserved for the last twenty eight years. This will supply the wants of the island, sal my warrant the restriction of light milway lines to the foot of the hills. But the availability of timber is of immense importance in mining, and in this respect it will not be the heavy burden spon industry in Cyprus that it is in Egypt Purther, in no part of Cyprus has one to go very far for water, so that in the two most vital factor of mineral development Cyprus is well placed.
GOLD AND SILVER
of these precious metals there is not very much evidence ; tro of gold there certainly are, bat mixed with baser metals; the same may be said of silver.
COPPER

Copper was worked in Cyprus from the very earliest times, and the scenes of the operations, chiefly in the Polis district, are yet marked by Large accumulations of slag, testifying to the past importance of this industry. There are thousands of tons of this slag, from which the metal has been completely extnoted.

So great were the exorvations that a large Inke was formed by the subsidence caused by the old workings falling in. Whether the ore was exhausted, or mining med owing to natural difficulties is not yet known, but thorough prospecting work is being undertaken by the Lamni Copper Company, work is being energetically pushed on, and the mine has been ones fully drained of water, that up to then had been source of great tabla. The prospectors have already driven through om, and are engaged in driving and cross cutting in the hopes of opening up further bodies. The company is formed in London, and should their operations prove successful, a never will have opened for the district
Samples and specimens of copper ore here come in from other places, and also tone con talking lead and iron
TERRA UMBER, ETC.
At Larnaca terme number is being exported in large quantities, and in the Paphos district great bodies of chrome have been found, and enn be placed upon the market at very little cost.

Cyprus Cyprus and its quality are too well known in Egypt, to require mention here, but the demand for it has been so great, especially from this country, as to necessitate the erection of several mills to cope with the increased output.

With such natural mineral resources only waiting the ad of capital to develop Cyprus cannot fall in the future, to, in no small way, revive the Busy scenes of Industry that the island formerly enjoyed; ad now only awaits the capital and experiener, that rander successful British rule, cannot fail to be diverted into the proper channels open to it

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The vacaat majority in the Coldstream Guards has been filled by the promotion Captain RA. Markham. Major Markham received his first mission in the Coldstream ers in December, 1890, and his company nine years later. He was attached to the Egyptian Army, 1899-1908, and was aide de camp to the Sirdar for a portion of that period. and participated in the first advance up the Nile, against the Khalifa (Egyptian medal with clasp).

Lieutenant RA. Bradford, King's Royal Rifle Corps serving with the 1st Battalion, Khartoum, has been promoted obtain after nearly eight year subaltern service Captain Bedford has had a varied service since he joined the army, having held appointments Excessively on the staff in South Africa during the war, under the Transvaal Civil Administration, and with the Transvaal Volunteers. He WM with the Rifles in Buller's actions for the relief of Ladysmith, including the affairs of Colenso, Spion Kop Tugela Heights, and Pieter's Hill, the operations in Orange Free State, Transvaal, and Cape Colony, being on the Intelligence staff in the latter part of the war (mentioned in despatches Queen's medal with six clasps King's modal with two clasps).

Many of your readers will be interested to learn that at the Colchester rifle meeting last Saturday, open to Regulars, Militia Yeomancy, and Volunteers, in the Eastern counties, Colour Sergeant Credon, of the King's Own Lancaster Regiment, made a record with the new rifle, sooring highest possibles in 10sion ad 900,500, and 600 yards, thus winning the Aggregate in the all.comers' match with 105 points.

It is stated that owing to possible complications in the Mediterranea, the Duke of Connaught will not be appointed to the command, which was the first arrangement. It is freely stated that the appointment of Commander in Chief of the army will be revived.

The keel plate of the new armoured cruiser called after Britain's patriotic but unfortunate queen-Boadices --- was laid at Pembroke Dock and this week. It is expected that the cruiser will be ready for the pennant by this time next year. The "Boadicea" is one of the Warrior" type of cruiser.
The Admiralty has decided to adopt the short spring bayonet as used in the army, to replace the present pattern in the Navy

div.head: REVOLT IN THE YEMEN. DEPUTATION AT YILDIZ KIOSK.
div.p: - The deputation of notables from the Yemen, who have been here for over a fortnight, during which time they have been treated with every honour, have at length entered into negotiations with the Palace, with a view to the re-establishment of peace in the Yemen.

It is understood that the deputation presented a petition to the Sultan, requesting that local autonomy should be granted, consenting to the appointment of Turkish civil inspectors, agreeing to the payment of an annual tribute, and commenting to mine a fighting force of 100,000 men in the event of jehad, or holy war. The petition also demands the appointment of local men m Governors of Kaim and Sandals.

The Turkish counter-proposals are stated to be follows: The nomination of local men a Governor of KM and Sandjaks, the remission of all arrears of taxes an important reduction in taxation, the formation of a local military corps on the model of the Hamidich Cavalry.

It is believed that some of the members of the deputation will soon leave on their return to the Yemea in order to submit the Turkish counter proposals to the lunam of Sana,, and receive his instructions.Reuter.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KARLBY AND CUNNINGHAM'S W
ELT RIPORT
LIVERPOOL, July 4. There has been slightly more enquiry for Egyptians this week, but the amount of actual business is still small. Quotations of Brown are raised 3/16 tot per tb. and Uppers per lb.
In Futures only a limited business has been done, and the following are the latest quotations : July 10.36 Oct. 10.31 Jan. 10:21 Aug. 10.84 Nov. 10,28 Peb. 10.21 Sep. 10.33 Deo. 10.24 Mar. 10.21

American Futures. The market this week has again provided a surprise, the last 3 or 4 official weekly weather conditions having been considered decidedly more favorable to the crop, but the monthly bureau estimate of 72% or an improvement for the whole month of only 1 % has startled all classes of operators, and caused an advance of 26 @ 80 points, There has been a reaction from the highest mtou touched yesterday, but closing prices are 21 @ 28 points higher for old crops, and 24 @ 25 points higher for the new crop portions, than those of last Thursday. The bureau raport is there however, but whether the June report which was better than expected, has been found too favorable, and the July report has suffered in consequence, it is difficult to say, but it has certainly come as a great shock and disappointment, because decidedly improved condition was generally expected. div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: KSC

A very interesting cricket match between the Officers and Non Commissioned Officers of the Inniskilling Dragoons was played at Ghezireh on Wednesday, the N.C.O. winning by 14. runs in the first innings. Sergeant Price played in excellent form and scored 81 not out ; he also took 4 wickets. The Non C.O. made a poor stand in their 2nd innings, and if time had permitted the Officers might have won on their second venture.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Alpinistratior a l'honneur de porter à la COnnaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu'à 1er Octobre 1907, à midi. des offres pour la fourniture de 310,000 "Trois cent dix mille tonnes Métriques de Charbon Welsh pendant l'arbre 1908 selon les conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au Bureau Central du Service des Maga 8:19 à Boulac (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandre) contre paiement de cent millièmes.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 Millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à Monsieur le Directeur Général Chemins de fer de l'Etat,
Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe intérieure portant la suscription suivante.

"Offre pour Charbon." L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter 1..Fre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux sou 111481 ons présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser le contrat Le Caire, le : Juillet 1907. 30593-9-9
